questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Two-Phase Commit (2PC) protocol?

options.A: To ensure high availability of services
options.B: To achieve consensus on transaction atomicity in distributed systems

questions.question: What are the two phases of the 2PC protocol?
What message does the coordinator send to initiate a transaction?
What does a participant do if it is able to commit a transaction?

options.B: It sends a VOTE_COMMIT message to the coordinator.
options.C: It waits for other participants to vote.
options.D: It sends an ACK message to the coordinator.

questions.question: When does the coordinator send a GLOBAL_COMMIT message?

options.A: As soon as one participant votes to commit.
options.C: When all participants have voted to commit.
options.D: It never sends a GLOBAL_COMMIT message.

questions.question: What happens if a participant votes to abort?

options.B: The coordinator asks the participant to vote again.
options.C: The coordinator forces the participant to commit.
options.D: The coordinator sends a GLOBAL_ABORT to all participants.

options.A: Participants block each other from accessing resources.
options.B: The coordinator blocks if it doesn't receive votes.
options.C: Participants that voted to commit may be blocked if the coordinator fails.
options.D: The network gets blocked with too many messages.

questions.question: How does a participant that failed after voting `VOTE_COMMIT` resolve its state upon recovery?

options.C: It contacts other participants to find out the decision.
options.D: It contacts the coordinator to find out the global decision.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key reason for using a `READY` log entry in a participant?

options.A: To inform the coordinator that it is alive.
options.B: To ensure that even if it fails, it remembers its vote and can determine the outcome correctly upon recovery.
options.C: To speed up the commit process.
options.D: To keep a count of the number of transactions.
